By Ujjwal Narayan and Siddhi Nayak
NewsRise
NEW DELHI (Jan 11) -- India’s Supreme Court today reserved judgement on Future Group’s plea seeking permission to go ahead with the Reliance Industries deal, amid an embittered legal battle with Amazon.

The top court also reserved judgement against Delhi High Court’s single judge order imposing status quo on the deal.

In 2019, Amazon invested $200 million in Future Coupons for a 49% stake, which gave the U.S. company a 7.3% foothold in flagship Future Retail. However, the two companies fell out after debt-laden Future Group agreed to sell its retail, wholesale, warehousing, and logistics businesses in August 2020 to billionaire Mukesh Ambani’s Reliance Industries in a $3.4 billion deal. The deal with Reliance is crucial to Future Group, which is on the brink of liquidation.

Amazon tried to block the deal by getting a freeze order from Singapore arbitration court. Future Group’s prospective sell out to Reliance threatens the U.S. company’s dominance in India.

“Our submission is this order (Arbitration Order) has to go,” Harish Salve, the counsel for Future Group argued. “This order was passed in complete breach of natural justice.”

Salve also invoked the number of job losses in case of Future Group companies going into bankruptcy, amid the protracted legal battle.

Meanwhile, the Competition Commission of India, last month, kept its approval for the 2019 deal between Amazon and Future on hold, accusing the U.S. e-commerce company of hiding information while seeking regulatory approval.
